title: How to Apply a French Polish

steps.headline: Begin with a clean, perfectly smooth wood surface and a clean, dust-free, warm room.
steps.description: Any imperfections in the wood or dust that settles onto the surface while you're working will show up in the polish. A cold room will cause the polish to be cloudy.

steps.headline: Mix 3 ounces of shellac flakes with 1 pint of denatured alcohol.
steps.description: Keep the mixture in a tightly sealed container, pouring small amounts into a shallow bowl as you work. Although you can buy shellac already mixed, the fresher it is, the better the results will be. Use gloves when working with shellac.

steps.headline: Soak a wad of gauze in shellac, then place it inside a cotton cloth (a piece of an old bed sheet or white tee-shirt works well).
steps.description: Tie up the ends of the cloth with string to make a sort of handle. Squeeze the pad to force most of the shellac out.

steps.headline: Add a few drops of olive oil to the pad.
steps.description: You may want to use an eyedropper to keep from adding too much. The purpose of the oil is to keep the pad from drying out and sticking as you apply shellac. If the pad does start to stick, add another couple of drops of oil.

steps.headline: Apply the shellac to the wood surface in a gliding or sweeping motion, working one small area at a time, perhaps 2 square feet.
steps.description: Gradually change to circular, then figure-8 motions. Each sweep will leave a thin layer of shellac, and your goal is to leave about 100 of these layers in one boding  session. The shellac will dry quickly, so using an improper motion will leave an imprint of the pad on the surface.

steps.headline: Build a fresh pad, then add a few drops shellac and several drops of alcohol to the cloth.
steps.description: Begin your stiffing session by sweeping the pad in even strokes from one side to the other to smooth out any unevenness in the shellac. Take care not to remove any shellac.

steps.headline: Allow the work to sit for a couple of hours so any oil can come to the surface.
steps.description: Then repeat the stiffing session to remove the oil. This is a separate step called spiriting.

steps.headline: Let the work sit for several hours so it can dry completely, then repeat the boding, stiffing and spiriting sessions.
steps.description: You will do this several times to build up a thick shellac surface on the wood.

steps.headline: Polish the surface with rottenstone and olive oil.
steps.description: Place the rottenstone in a salt shaker and sprinkle it on the surface, then apply a few drops of olive oil to a fresh pad and rub the entire surface until you're satisfied with its appearance.

steps.headline: Finish with a thin coat of furniture wax to help protect your French polish from damage.

text: Begin with a clean, perfectly smooth wood surface and a clean, dust-free, warm room. Any imperfections in the wood or dust that settles onto the surface while you're working will show up in the polish. A cold room will cause the polish to be cloudy. Mix 3 ounces of shellac flakes with 1 pint of denatured alcohol. Keep the mixture in a tightly sealed container, pouring small amounts into a shallow bowl as you work. Although you can buy shellac already mixed, the fresher it is, the better the results will be. Use gloves when working with shellac. Soak a wad of gauze in shellac, then place it inside a cotton cloth (a piece of an old bed sheet or white tee-shirt works well). Tie up the ends of the cloth with string to make a sort of handle. Squeeze the pad to force most of the shellac out. Add a few drops of olive oil to the pad. You may want to use an eyedropper to keep from adding too much. The purpose of the oil is to keep the pad from drying out and sticking as you apply shellac. If the pad does start to stick, add another couple of drops of oil. Apply the shellac to the wood surface in a gliding or sweeping motion, working one small area at a time, perhaps 2 square feet. Gradually change to circular, then figure-8 motions. Each sweep will leave a thin layer of shellac, and your goal is to leave about 100 of these layers in one boding  session. The shellac will dry quickly, so using an improper motion will leave an imprint of the pad on the surface. Build a fresh pad, then add a few drops shellac and several drops of alcohol to the cloth. Begin your stiffing session by sweeping the pad in even strokes from one side to the other to smooth out any unevenness in the shellac. Take care not to remove any shellac. Allow the work to sit for a couple of hours so any oil can come to the surface. Then repeat the stiffing session to remove the oil. This is a separate step called spiriting. Let the work sit for several hours so it can dry completely, then repeat the boding, stiffing and spiriting sessions. You will do this several times to build up a thick shellac surface on the wood. Polish the surface with rottenstone and olive oil. Place the rottenstone in a salt shaker and sprinkle it on the surface, then apply a few drops of olive oil to a fresh pad and rub the entire surface until you're satisfied with its appearance. Finish with a thin coat of furniture wax to help protect your French polish from damage.
